review_title: Good place to start your career
pros: Good place to start your career, amazing facility, lots of new content/workshops per month, hybrid model, good brand for your CV, free coffee/snacks.
cons: The positions are not examined equaly, you will see people as Managers with 2 years of experience and also with 15 years of experience and that means they both get the same salary. Promotions are hardly given and the salary increase is pretty low. A senior manager earns 5% more than a manager and so on. The most suitable option is to aquire the best contract at the beggining (highest position possible for you) because you are going to stay in that position for many years regardless your efforts. Almost zero utilization for most employees most of the day is spent just doing nothing instead of providing your skills to crucial operations of the organization. Compared to other companies the benefits are pretty low you get a car after becoming a Director (hardly ever) which in other brands you can get a car from a position of assistant manager. The salary is mediocre for high positions (Manager and above) and low for junior positions such as associate/sr.associate compared to other companies. The company in Greece is HR driven (greek HR) which means what ever your Manager decides for you (promotion,raise,relocation,benefits) has to be accepted from the HR first (hardly ever happens).

review_title: Center of Digital Innovation with ZERO Innovation
pros: - Compared to city standards, it's OK workplace - Brand - Perks - Young environment (let's say is good) - Have fun, relax, nice espresso
cons: - It's an IT department. A support/operational/execution center. There's no innovation. - You can barely find teams that are built based on skills or previous experience. - Zero growth/career plan - they give you access to a bunch of learning platforms but they don't really care or assist you with what you should learn and how to grow. Wouldn't be surprised if i see QA people with "Making the first drug in practice for dummies" certification. - Engineers less than 5-10%. If you find some then they are under-utilised. - Hierarchy based place. - Roles VS Experience is an issue in there. You can find lots of people with more that 15y of experience and yet are Sr Associates and Managers with 2/3y of experience. - Salaries are bad calculated. - Old tech to work with. - Work life balance is not that good but I've seen many people working extra hours - mainly because of the US/UK overlap. - Old fashioned US/UK managers with zero tech background - Definitely not a place for Engineers

review_title: Good benefits/pay but growth opportunities and promotions are not consistent between groups
pros: Good pay and good benefits
cons: Growth opportunities and promotions are completely dependent on your group and boss, which can be good or bad for you. It was bad for me. I watched other colleagues that possessed similar skills/experience/capabilities as myself get promoted, and in some cases, get promoted more than once, before I received a single promotion. I intend to leave the company soon to find my next step since Pfizer continues to move the target for what is needed to promote me. I've been on the promotion list for ~1.5 years now and have no indication that I will be promoted anytime soon.

job_title: Operations Technician Assistant in Kalamazoo, MI
pros: Benefits are good and the caregiver and sick days helped compensate for no work life balance.
cons:
No work life balance for certain departments. In injectable filling, your opinion doesn't matter about the future scheduling taking away or weekend pay or anything that pertains to you. Higher ups act like they want to know what you think but whatever you say falls on deaf ears.

There is a second shift supervisor who is the most by the book guy I have worked for. Everything is black and white in his mind, and he just wants to climb the ladder. He does not have your back and I did not get my exit interview because it would have been with him, not HR. Even if I did do my exit interview, I would not have been able to comfortably express my concerns or known if they would have moved upwards or just trashed. 

I also have a same sex partner and submitted Pfizer's paper work to have them put on my insurance to no avail after months of contacting and questioning about the application. They fly the rainbow flag in June but prepare to jump through hoops if you have a same sex partner and are trying to get them on your benefits. You'd do better to have a courthouse wedding than try to enroll them as your domestic partner.

cons: - Leadership is all big talk and very little actual action - Culture is very toxic in most teams - everyone is constantly worried about losing their jobs - Very political in nature, have to be very measured in what you say - Meritocracy takes a back seat. As long as you tow the leadership line, you can get away with anything and everything - They say they encourage folks to be innovative and are interested in people continuing at Pfizer long term, but tenured employees have a racket and it is difficult to survive if you are new to the organization and enterprising.

job_title: Software Engineer (Mid-level) in San Diego, CA
pros:
* Good work/life balance
* Immediate teammates are great to work with
* Health insurance cost/coverage is good (that's the only good benefit)
* Company mission (if not execution) is noble
* Free cold brew at San Diego site.
cons:
* Mediocre salary (which is based only on pharma peers, not role or job type peer groups, nor local cost of living).
* Top leadership in Digital organization have minimal experience in the "meat" of their teams; they're frequently shuffled around in order to continue justifying promoting them.
* Career progress is often based on meeting demographic checkboxes or personal favoring, with "meeting planners" and "paper pushers" being preferred to people with actual skills.
* Technical roles in the US are currently being moved to Greece so if you're in the US in such a role, you don't have any meaningful future in Digital.
* LTIs are often not worth very much, and only vest as a single lump-sum
* Site in San Diego is quite long in the tooth; refreshes that are happening are very superficial. Cafeteria is overpriced and average quality.

review_title: Are you a new grad? Welcome to a NEW PFIZER EXPERIENCE!!
pros: Starting post pandemic, everyone will have the option of going into the office anywhere from 0-3 days...essentially making everyone remote. If your manger is okay with not coming in at all, then you're fully remote with the option of going into work at whatever Pfizer site is nearest you. Ever since our new CEO stepped into the role in 2019 we are in a whole new Pfizer. He is striving to build a distinct culture of growth mindset, learning, and inclusion. May not seem like a big deal but it is when your employer invests in ways to upskill yourself whether they apply to your role or not. You're also encouraged to learn about anything you want and ask for projects outside the boundaries of your team/group. Networking is super easy, never had anyone turn down an 'ask' to meet. People are generally very engaged. I'm in the first 3 years of my career at Pfizer (started here) and have found it very fluid to navigate. Oh and the work life balance is out of this world. If you're black or latino .. their affinity resource groups are extremely powerful and visibly supported by senior leadership and afford you a ton of visibility so definitely join them! Pro tip: make friends in HR!!!!
cons: For the immense flexibility, great networking opportunities, work-life balance, benefits, vacation time, .... they will not compete with tech salaries ever. So if you're thinking about a tech salary here, look elsewhere. Pfizer makes up for it in other places, depends on what lifestyle you're hoping to have.

review_title: potential to be an excellent work place, but many issues
pros:
There are a lot of amazing scientists and leaders here who are also humble enough to recognize the hard work of others and mentor their people to reach the next step in their career. They recognize that elevating their people elevates them. 

Work life balance is decent but could depend on your group structure and function.
cons:
Unnecessary political games being played. Some toxic managers have favorites that aren't even based on merit, are clueless about the actual science going on, and are only concerned about optics to leadership. 

Pfizer is also underpaid compared to other local pharma companies, but they attempt to make it up to us with small, non-monetary perks like occasional free lunch or happy hours.

pros:
I have joined Pfizer as a Country Trials Manager of Global Site & Study Operations (GSSO) team within CDO / GPD for Ukraine Cluster with effective date 04/Nov/2021. I am accountable for study startup deliverables for assigned studies at a country level of limited or moderate complexity partnering with the Study Start Up Project Manager, Study Manager, Site Intelligence Lead, Site Relationship Partner, Site Activation Partner, Contracts Lead, Regulatory Affairs, CRO representatives and others. 

I have started my career from the position of Project Assistant in Ltd. PSI-Ukraine CRO in January 2009.In October 2011 I became a Senior Clinical Project Administrator in Covance Inc being responsible for start-up activities and trial maintenance lifecycle. 

In October 2012 I have proceeded my carrier development as Clinical Research Associate with further development to CRA II, SrCRA and Senior Clinical Site Manager in PAREXEL LLC performing site monitoring and management within endocrinology, cardiology, neurology, immunology, psychiatry and oncology studies in Ukraine Phase II-III and USA Phase I.

In January 2020 I made a new career step as Clinical Operations Leader (COL) in PAREXEL International. I have performed global trial management in EMEA and AMER region within oncology studies. During my carrier, I have led the organization to develop, implement and achieve its mission, vision and goals while continuing clinical trials management. 

I have a BA degree in Business Administration in Management graduating International Christian University Vienna-Kyiv (ICU-Kyiv) as well as master’s degree in Pharmacy at PHEE Kyiv Medical University of UAFM-Kiev. I have over 13 years of experience in clinical trial industry, which practically includes all stages of study execution. 
In November 2021 I have started my further career development within GSSO Pfizer team, however prior I have been outsoared for Pfizer trails starting 2012.

review_title: Can't believe it's been 20+ years of Pfizer!
pros:
Great company to work for. Mostly fantastic leaders. I've had 17 different direct managers, learned something from all of them. So many opportunities for development (and encouraged by leadership).
Pfizer is really working hard to strike the right balance between work and family life. They're doing a great job and I'm very grateful to have had such an amazing place to work. 
Having a company like Pfizer on your business card brings strength and respect to your role and engagement with customers. People notice.
cons:
The company is VERY big and can get caught up in processes (i.e., survey question they work on every year is "It's easy to get things done at Pfizer."). Lots of process and legal, but it's expected in our industry.
For a company with cutting edge therapies, they are a little slow on the technology uptake (although working on it). Some software programs are clunky.

job_title: Senior Scientist in San Diego, CA
pros: I've never been more proud to work at a pharmaceutical company than being at Pfizer during the pandemic. Albert Bourla (CEO) truly seems to be focused on getting medicine to patients in need and "moving at the speed of science" rather than caving to outside pressures. The company supports a healthy work-life balance and provides good benefits and perks (monthly happy hours pre-pandemic, walking challenges to earn money off your health insurance premium, $500-1000 cash bonuses for going above and beyond your job).
cons: It is a big company and there are a lot of middle managers who tend to focus on either their own egos or their limited perspective, rather than soliciting feedback from the people in the lab who actually do the work. There is a lot of internal politics, particularly in groups with people who have been with the company for a long time (i.e. lots of change-resistant people/managers). There are frequent reorgs/layoffs, so there's always an underlying fear that you or your group could be deemed unnecessary next. It can also be difficult to work across groups (often due to the politics), which can limit career and growth opportunities.
